content: The "no space left on device" error indicates that the partition or file system is full. You will need to free up space by removing unnecessary files or increasing the partition size. You can use the "df -h" command to check the available disk space and identify the partition that is full. Then remove any unnecessary files or increase the partition size using a tool like "gparted".
This is an XFS file system. It will not mount, so I cannot remove files. And it is also a logical volume.

In that case, try running the command "xfs_repair -n /dev/<logical_volume>" to check for any errors on the XFS file system. If there are any errors, try repairing them with the command "xfs_repair /dev/<logical_volume>". If the issue still persists, it could be an issue with the logical volume. You may need to increase the size of the logical volume using a tool like "lvextend" or "xfs_growfs" to free up disk space.
XFS repair fails with a PWRITE64 failed input-output error.

The "PWRITE64 failed input-output error" suggests that there might be a hardware issue with the disk. You could try checking the disk for any bad sectors using the command "badblocks -v /dev/<logical_volume>". If you find any bad sectors, you may need to replace the disk. If the disk is healthy, you may need to restore the XFS file system from the backups, if available.
What's the best daily note-taking software to use for Mac OS?

Some popular daily note-taking software for Mac OS include Evernote, Apple Notes, and Microsoft OneNote. Other great options include Bear and Notion, which offer advanced features such as tagging, organization, and collaboration. The best one for you may depend on your specific needs and preferences, so it's worth trying out a few to find the right fit.
